loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
This is 33-year-old Mohamed. He is married and has two children aged five and one. In 2003, Mohamed established his top-up cards for mobile phones business. He began his business because he wanted to increase his income, be self-employed, and get a permanent means of providing a livelihood to his family.

Working six days a week and 13 hours a day, he earns about 700,000 Sierra Leonean leones (SLL) every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of 3,500,000 SLL. Mohamed requires a loan in order to buy more mobile phones and top-up cards for his business. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 200,000 SLL. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more recharge cards and mobile phones

loans.name: Kimren

texts.en: Kimren, 61, resides in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Kimren is a farmer who grows bananas, corn, and beans, earning an income of USD 14.7 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 66 on food and USD 85 on the other necessary expenses. Kimren is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase bananas to stock and resell. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy bananas to stock and resell

loans.name: Dominic

texts.en:
Dominic is 55 years old and married with eight children, six of whom are currently in school. He has a poultry farm in the outskirts of Kitale town in western Kenya where he has been farming for 10 years. He employs one farmhand and sells his products to the local market. He also earns additional income from the sale of sugarcane, vegetables, and milk. 

Dominic has requested this loan of 60,000 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to buy additional chickens and build a poultry house. This he says, would improve his production capacity and increase his marginof profit. In future, he plans to expand his poultry farm by increasing the number of layers and constructing a better poultry house. He faces a transportation challenge getting his products to the market due to a poor network of roads.

loans.use: To buy chickens and build a poultry house.

loans.name: Phann

texts.en:
Mrs. Phann is shown in the photo. She is a resident of Siem Reap Province. Selling porridge is her daily activity to earn money and feed her children. Besides this business, she sells various items in front of her house, to villagers and other travelers, earning approximately US$3 a day for these activities.

To share responsibility with Mrs. Phann, her husband works as a car taxi driver. At present, the couple lives with three single children, two of whom are employed in various job to earn an income, while the other seven are married and live in their own houses. Mrs. Phann is requesting a loan to buying a new motorbike for her employed children, so they can reduce the costs of their work commute.

loans.use: buy a new motorbike for her children to ride to work.

loans.name: Zumratkhon's Group

texts.en:
Zumratkhon is the leader of this group. She is 48 and married to a farmer. Together with her husband she has raised a son and two daughters. The son works as a butcher; the first daughter is married and the second is still single. In order to earn money, the family breeds cattle. Zumratkhon also sells dairy products. In this way she earns an additional 1875 soms per month. She applied for the loan because she needs additional funds to purchase a calf. In the future Zumratkhon plans to increase the number of cattle and start building a house for her son.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a calf

loans.name: Saima's Group

texts.en:
Saima has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her husband’s crockery selling business. He operates his business on a cart. He sells crockery items like cups, teapots, glasses etc. He is very fair in his rates and makes good profits from his business. With the loan, he will buy crockery items to offer more variety to his customers, which will help him increase his profits and sales. He has had this business for the past nine years and Saima hopes that a loan will bring positive changes to his business and improves his income. 

Saima herself is a housewife who stays at home and does her household responsibilities. She is a very active and responsible person and performs her tasks very well. She has given birth to four children: two sons and two daughters. Only her eldest son is enrolled in a school. The others are very young and have not started their education yet. 

Saima is a very responsible loan user of Asasah. She has been receiving loans from Asasah for the past four years. She has always paid her installments on time and attended every meeting.

loans.use: To buy crockery to sell

loans.name: Laiheng

texts.en: Laiheng, 54, resides in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Laiheng is a farmer, earning an income of USD 2 per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband is a traditional musician and purchases cows to resell, earning an income of USD 8 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 56 on food and USD 25 on the other necessary expenses. Laiheng is requesting a loan of USD 900 to purchase more cows to resell. This will be her first from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more cows to resell

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is 47 year-old. He has four children aged 10, 7, 4 and one years. In 1996, Ibrahim established a spare parts and lubricants business. He began his business because he needed a means of providing for his family. Working 7 days a week and 14 hours a day, he earns about Le 900,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000 to buy a drum of engine oil, break oil and oil filters for his business. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 200,000. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy auto parts and engine oil

loans.name: Ambrose

texts.en:
Ambrose is a farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for the last 6 years and employs one farmhand. He sells his milk, tomatoes, and beans to the local market. He mainly depends on the income from his farm to cater to the basic needs of his family. Ambrose is 37 years old and married with five children.

He has requested for this loan of 31,200 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from the sale of milk will enable him to improve the living standards of his family. His biggest challenge has been competition from other farmers and this has affected the market prices of farm products. He however hopes to expand his farm and improve the quality of his dairy cows in the near future.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Sareoun

texts.en: Sareoun, 35, resides in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for its rubber plantation. Sareoun is a farmer, earning an income of USD 2.4 per day to help cover her family's expenses. Her husband purchases mango stock to resell, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 66 on food and USD 60 on the other necessary expenses. Sareoun is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase cashew nuts and peanuts in stock to resell. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy cashew nuts and peanuts to resell.

loans.name: Kholmuhamad

texts.ru: Холмухамад проживает в районе Хамадони. Ему 52 года. Он женат. У него четверо детей. Его жена домохозяйка. Сам он более 20 лет занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет небольшой земельный участок, где выращивает овощи и сажает фруктовые деревья. В этом ему помогают двое его дочки. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений. Он хочет посеять и получить хороший урожай для продажи.
texts.en: Kholmuhamad lives in the Hamadoni region. He is 52 years old. He is married and has four children. His wife is a homemaker. He has been in the agriculture for more than twenty years. He has a small plot of land near his home where he grows vegetables and plants fruit trees. His two daughters are helping him in this business. He is taking out the loan to buy mineral fertilizer. He wants to sow and gather a good harvest for resale.

loans.use: to buy mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a motorbike for transporting vegetables to sell and for providing transportation services.

loans.name: Zaitoon's Group

texts.en:
Zaitoon is 43 years old, married and has a son. Zaitoon couldn’t educate her son due to financial constraints. He helps his father run a shoe making business. Both are very hard workers. They take orders from different shoe shops and fulfill their orders on time to make profits. 

Zaitoon is a housewife who stays at home and does her household responsibilities. She is a caring and responsible person by nature. She manages her household expenses very responsibly. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who wants to improve his business further. With the loan, he will buy required items such as nails, glue, leather and shoe polish in bulk to be able to make a larger quantity of shoes and earn more profits. He has been operating this business for the past 20 years and Zaitoon is very hopeful that a loan will bring more profits to him and increase his income.

loans.use: To buy items required for the shoe-making business

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: This is 46 year-old Alice. She is married and has three children ages 4, 18, and 22 years old. She has two dependents, one who is a relative.  In 1991, Alice established her local food stuff business. Working seven days a week and thirteen hours a day, she earns about Le 600,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. Alice requires a loan in order to purchase more local food stuffs for her business. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 150,000. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more local food stuffs for her business.

loans.name: Bilqees' Group

texts.en: Bilqees is married with four sons. Two of them work and the other two are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. Her eldest son has a sofa cover fitting business and the second son one sells perfumes. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who runs two businesses simultaneously. He sells religious book and vegetables. He has a small shop in the community market where he operates his businesses. He will use the loan money to buy religious books and fresh seasonal vegetables to fulfill the needs of his customers and earn a good profit. He has been operating this business for the past eight years and Bilqees is hopeful that his business will grow further after the loan investment. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fourth loan application. In her previous loans, she maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy religious books and fresh seasonal vegetables

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex has been practicing mixed farming for the last ten years in Kitale town in western Kenya. His farm produces milk, bananas, eggs, and maize which are all sold to the local market. He earns additional income from his food kiosk in the same location. 

Alex has made his fourth loan request of 40,000 Kes from Juhudi Kilimo in order to expand his poultry farm. He intends to use this loan to purchase additional stock of poultry and construct a better poultry house. He says that this will help him practice commercial poultry farming and this will increase his profits. The extra income from this loan will help improve his family's livelihood. In the future, he would like to keep exotic breeds of poultry for both broilers and layers.

Alex is 35 years old and married with seven children.

loans.use: To expand his poultry farm.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his poultry farm.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
This is Teresita, 59, resident of Tala, Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Domingo, a driver, and she is a mother of four children, three of whom are already working while the other one is still in school. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her remaining children all the way through college. This would be a dream for most Filipino parents like Teresita,  as she herself believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Teresita operates a furniture making business. She mainly offers household and office furniture like chairs, tables, filing cabinets, closet, among others.  She also accepts orders from customers who want furniture of their own design and style.  Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 12,000 a month.

To help her continue her business operations, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like hard wood, paints, nails, and others. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Teresita dreams to be able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all of her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw materials needed for furniture making.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
This is Helen, 42, resident of Guadanoville, Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Romeo, a mechanic, and she is a mother to four children, two of whom are already studying in college and the other two are in high school. She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Helen operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries, and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Helen earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 22,000 loan. She will utilize the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Helen hopes to be able to expand her business soon and be able to send all of her children all the way through college. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional grocery items needed for her variety store.

loans.name: Muniran's Group

texts.en:
Muniran is 55 years old, married and has a son. She was not able to provide an education to her son due to financial constraints. He is an embroidery expert now and helps his father in his decorative embroidery business.
Muniran is a housewife who stays at home to take care of her household tasks. She is still very active and completes her daily tasks efficiently. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, to improve her son’s embroidery business because he wants to start a business independently. With the loan, he will buy colored thread, patterns and cloth to make embroidered dresses to meet customer demand and earn more profits. Muniran is confident that an investment will help him start a profitable business.
Muniran is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained good credit behavior and has never missed any meeting.
Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Muniran.

loans.use: to buy colored thread, patterns and cloth for her son's embroidery business.

loans.name: Rahima

texts.ru: Рахима проживает в районе Шахринав. Возраст, 40 лет. Замужем. У нее четверо детей. Ее муж работает в джамоате района. Сама Рахима занимается растениеводством. Она в основном выращивает овощи для продажи. Этим видом деятельности занимается 15 лет. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений.
texts.en: Rahima lives in the Shahrinav region. She is 40 years old. She is married and has four children. Her husband works in the regional village council. Rahima does agriculture. She mainly grows vegetables for resale. She has been in this business for fifteen years. She is taking the loan to buy mineral fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 40 years old and married with four school-aged children who all attend school. She is a farmer from the town of Kitale in western Kenya where she has been farming for ten years. She sells her milk, beans, maize, and eggs to the local market. She mainly depends on the income from her farm to cater for the basic needs of her family. 

Rose has requested a loan of 31,200 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says that with the dairy cow that she will acquire, her family will be guaranteed enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The profits from the sale of milk will help her provide for the basic needs of her family. She faces the challenge of diseases and food shortage during the dry season. She hopes to acquire at least five dairy cows in the next five years.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Jonjib

texts.en:
Jonjib, who is 29 years old, lives in the community of Sta. Josefa Agusan Del Sur. He is a rice farmer and a piggery owner. He has been in this business for 12 years. 

Through a loan from Community Economic Ventures Inc., he will buy farm and agricultural supplies, such as fertilizers and seeds.

Jonjib is childless. His dream is to become a successful rice farmer in the future.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Mercily

texts.en:
This is Mercily, 47, a resident of Malaria, Caloocan City, Philippines. She is a single parent and a mother of two children.  One child is now in college, and the other is getting a high school education.  At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her children's everyday expenses.

Mercily operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries, and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Mercily earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Mercily hopes to be able to expand her business soon and eventually become a big convenience store.  She also prays for good health to be enjoyed by everybody in her house. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional grocery items to add to her variety store.

loans.name: Ma. Luisa

texts.en:
Ma. Luisa is 45 years old and married with 2 children.  She works hard to provide for her family.  She runs a Sari sari store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 24500 loan through NWTF, to buy items like shampoo, groceries etc. to sell in her store .

Ma. Luisa has borrowed and paid 17 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the Sari sari store for 11 years and also earns an income from buying and selling vegetables and spices.

Ma. Luisa aspires to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: Buy items to sell in her sari-sari store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a dairy farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya, where she has been farming for seven years. Her mixed farm produces milk, maize, and beans which are all sold to the local market. Farming has been her main source of income.

Jane has requested this loan of 31,200 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The proceeds from the sale of milk will help her pay school fees for her four children who are currently attending school. Her biggest challenge has been transportation of her products to the market due to poor road transport network in the area. She plans to expand her dairy farming in the next future by acquiring at least five dairy cows.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily is 46 years old and married with 5 children.

Emily works hard to provide for her family. She runs a Sari-sari store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 10000 loan through NWTF.  This loan will help her buy additional items like sardines, groceries, etc to sell in her Sari-sari store.

Emily has borrowed and paid 7 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 21 years, and also earns an income from electronic reloading.

Emily aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: buy additional items to sell in her store

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en:
Alfredo is 52 and is a married man with six children. The oldest child is 13. 

Alfredo is a farmer working in Sta. Josefa, Agusan del Sur. He has been growing rice for seven years. He earns 8,000 PHP per month doing this farming. 

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds. In the future, he hopes to improve his living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds for his farming.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en: Myrna, a 56-year-old married mother of five children, works hard to provide for her family selling spices in the Philippines, a business she has operated for 21 years. She also earns an income from operating a general store and selling vegetables. Myrna, who has borrowed and repaid 14 loans from NWTF, is requesting a PHP 21000 loan through NWTF to puchase additional stocks of spices to sell. Myrna aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of spices to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
As a married mother of one child, Analyn works hard to support her family.

She has a food production and vending business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from farming rice. 

Analyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past five loans from NWTF. 

Analyn is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production and vending business. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her food production business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Salina

texts.en:
Salina is 37 years old, married, and she has five children ages eighteen, fifteen, eleven, nine, and seven years old.  Salina sells milk in Languse trading center and has been in the business for a period of three years earning a monthly income of KES.2,500.

Salina is borrowing a loan from KADET LTD of KES. 15,000, in other words this is her first term loan.  She intends to use the amount to purchase one dairy dairy cow and one sheep. The anticipated profit will be used to purchase a plot and build rental houses.

Her dream is to improve the welfare of her family.

loans.use: purchase one dairy cow and one sheep.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn, 53, is married and has seven children. Two are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Jocelyn has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 30 years.

Jocelyn requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to purchase spare parts, gasoline and engine oil.

 In the future, Jocelyn would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts, gasoline and engine oil.

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en:
Rosie is married and 57 years old. She has a retail shop where she sells both food and daily use products such as soap and shampoo to the people in her community. She has had this business for five years.

Rosie is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase more retail items such as detergents, canned goods, and soft drinks.

In the future, Rosie hopes to see her small store grow into a big one and be able to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell such as detergents, canned goods, and softdrinks

loans.name: Divina

texts.en:
Divina is 48 years old and has two children. She is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. 

Divina has been raising pigs for 20 years now, and has borrowed eight times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

Divina has requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Divina would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Amartuvshin

texts.en: Amartuvshin is 38 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a ger, a Mongolian yurt, in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. His two children, ages 13 and 14, both attend local secondary school. He manages a taxi service business in his town. He started his business in 2007 and gained much experience. He is a safe and reliable driver who provides comfortable service for his customers. Now he has lots of regular customers and is planning to continue his business in the future. In addition, he also is planning to manage a grocery trading business with the help of his wife so that he can earn more money that will assist in paying his children's tuition fees. He is a polite man who says, "I want to expand my business and to open my grocery store in near future." He is requesting a 1,800,000 MNT loan to purchase grocery items and to rent a stall.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items.

loans.name: Ban

texts.en:
Ban is the mother of three single children, and one of them is working in the garment factory and has a formal salary. 

To earn a living, Ban sells many kinds of items in a wooden kiosk next to her house. In addition, she also raises a few piglets behind her house for making more income. 

She has a life partner in her husband who sells firewood in and around his village, Baray district. 

Ban would like to request a loan to build a new kitchen room in her house so that she can cook meals for all members of her family.

loans.use: to build a new kitchen room in her house.

loans.name: Nyabuto

texts.en:
Nyabuto is 39 yrs old and married to Nancy who contributes to the income of the family. They have one child who is nineteen years old. Nyabuto has been running his farm for a period of about seven years with an income of KES.12,000 a month.

This is his second loan with Kadet after repaying the previous one successfully. He wants to use this loan to pay the school fees for his child. 

His hopes and dreams are to educate his child up to the highest level of education and thus improve his child's future.

loans.use: He wants to use the loan to pay the school fees for his child.

loans.name: Juma

texts.en:
Juma is a married man with three children, all of whom attend school. They own a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, he has operated a retail shop business, selling to his neighbours and passersby. He sells house hold consumptions like beans, rice, and sugar. Juma faces a major obstacle of high cost of transportation in his business. 

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase two sacks beans and two sacks of sugar. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase two sacks, beans, and two sacks of sugar.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
This is Evelyn, 34, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Paulino, a vendor, and mother to their child. She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Evelyn operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries, and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Evelyn earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, Evelyn is requesting a Php 14,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Evelyn hopes to be able to expand soon to increase her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery products and other inventory items needed for her variety store.

loans.name: Mehrangez

texts.en:
Mehrangiz is 29 years old. She is a hardworking woman. She is married and has two children. Her husband works as a butcher. Mehrangez sells perfume and different spirits in the center of market “Farovon”. She buys her goods from Khujand city from the company of “Oriflame.” She always buys high quality products and that’s why she has many regular clients and many orders. Mehrangiz would like to get a loan of 5,000 TJS to purchase new assortments of perfume in order to increase cosmetics and fragrance sales. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: purchase new assortments of perfume in order to increase cosmetics and fragrance sales.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia is 48 years old and is a married woman with three children. The oldest child is 25. Her husband works as a farmer. 

She is a farmer working in Sta. Josefa, Agusan del sur. She has been farming for three years. She earns 15,000 PHP per month doing this farming. Alicia also owns and manages a sari-sari store. She sells vegetables, canned goods, and other products.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds. In the future, she hopes to succeed in her farming business and reach her dreams in life.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds.

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha is 39 years, a widow, and has two school going children.  She has been selling fruits and vegetables in Naivasha town for the last four years.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan amount to add to her shop's stock, which includes cabbages, maize, and carrots.

In the future, Tabitha hopes to buy a pick up truck, which she will use to ferry the produce direct from the farms for herself.

loans.use: add stock in her shop like cabbages, carrots, and maize.

loans.name: Munansi Development Group A

texts.en:
Jane, 30, is a genial, sturdy and resolute business woman who carries a firm conviction that the future prospects in her decade-long retail business will be in the ascendancy as long as she remains focused and keeps streamlining her business plans.

The happily married mother of two believes she will always do better financially in her business if she keeps restocking her retail shop with commodities that many people in her Mubende area are partial too. 

At present, she principally sells soap, rice, beans and ground nuts. She says that her weekly business sales profits are to the tune of UGX 180,000.

Prior to taking root in this business, Jane was involved in a small agriculture business. She still ekes out profits from this business though she says it is more of a second-fiddle business now. 

With this Kiva loan, she says she is going to purchase more retail commodities to resell. She anticipates more sales revenue in the future out of reselling more of what she buys.

In the group photo, a lady client by the name of Annet had her face inadvertently covered by the lead client's raised hand.

loans.use: to purchase more retail commodities to resell.

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz is 53 years old and is a married woman with three children. The oldest child is 32. Her husband works as a farmer. 

Beatriz is also a farmer working in Sta. Josefa, Agusan del sur. She has been growing rice for 10 years. Beatriz also raises pigs in her backyard. She built a small piggery that she hopes to expand soon. Beatriz sells her pigs at the market.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers for her rice field and to feed her pigs. In the future, she hopes to be successful in her livelihood.

loans.use: to purchase farm fertilizers and pig feed.

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en:
Bernadette is now 47 years old and married with three school-aged children. Bernadette is a farmer working in the Philippines who earns PHP 7,000 per month. 

Bernadette is asking for a loan of PHP 15,000 to purchase fertilizers and pesticides. Bernadette has been growing rice for almost 15 years.

In the future, Bernadette hopes to have a large production of rice in order to earn more income to finance the schooling of her children who are now in college. She believes that with the continuous support of the Kiva lenders, she can achieve her business goals through her patience and strong determination.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Safarbi

texts.ru: Сафарби проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 58 лет. Вдова, имеет 6 детей. Двое ее сыновей находятся в Российской Федерации на заработках. Сама Сафарби занимается животноводством. Она разводит крупнорогатый скот у себя дома. В основном она откармливает и продает скот. Этим видом деятельности занимается 20 лет. Кредит берет для закупа дойной коровы и двух голов бычков.
texts.en: Safarbi lives in the Hamadoni District. 58 years of age. A widow, with six children. Two of her sons are migrant workers in the Russian Federation. Safarbi raises livestock. She keeps cattle by her home. Her main business activity is fattening cattle for sale. She has been doing this for 20 years. She is taking out a loan to buy a milk cow and two bulls.

loans.use: to buy a milk cow and two bulls

loans.name: Miranda

texts.en:
Miranda is a 42-year-old woman married to a utility worker named Mariano and together they raise their three children. Miranda has had a food selling business for three years. She sells fruits and vegetables to the people in her community. She earns approximately PHP 5,000 monthly.

Miranda is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy fish and meat to sell and hogs to raise. In the future, Miranda hopes to earn more profit and lift her family out of poverty.

loans.use: to buy fish and meat to sell and hogs to raise.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 30 years old, married to Maleyo,and they have four children.  She has operated her barber shop in Naivasha for the last year.

She was introduced to KADET LTD, by one her friends and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the loan amount to buy a battery charger to be able to cushion herself from a loss of business when there is power outage.

In the future, Susan hopes to enlarge her barber shop and open up a salon with a beauty shop.

loans.use: To buy a battery charger to be able to cushion herself from a loss of business when there is power outage.

loans.name: Danny

texts.en:
Danny is 32 years old and is a married man with four children. The oldest child is 11. 

He is a farmer working in Sta. Josefa, Agusan del sur. He has been growing rice for 5 years. Danny is also a driver and hog-raiser. He uses his motorcycle to transport people around his community. He raises his pigs in his backyard. Danny works hard to provide for his family. 

This loan will be used to purchase feeds and for motorcycle repair. In the future, he hopes that his children will finish their studies.

loans.use: to purchase pig feed and repair his motorcycle.

loans.name: Azam

texts.en:
Azam is a 47 year old man. He is married and he has four children. Azam is engaged in a farming business and for 20 years he has been running this business. Azam cultivates agricultural products such as wheat, barley, and watermelons. His wife and son help him to process land and sow seeds. The he keeps part of his crop for his family and the rest he sells at the market. Azam would like to get a loan of 10,000 TJS for purchasing fertilizers and fuel and lubricating materials in order to make a good profit and provide for his family’s needs. 
    
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, fuel, and lubricating materials for his farming business.

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin is married and 62 years old. He has a service shop where he repairs shoes and bags. Benjamin had this business for five years.

Benjamin is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy materials used in making bags and shoes like leather, shoe nails, etc. Each month, Benjamin earns about PHP 3,000 doing this type of work.

In the future, Benjamin hopes that his business will become more progressive to sustain the needs of his family.

loans.use: to buy materials used to make bags and shoes like leather, shoe nails etc

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is 36 years old, married to Alice, and they have one child.  Simon has operated his motorbike business in Naivasha town for the last one year.

Simon was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy farm produce like potatoes, maize, and transport them to the market for sale . 

In the future, Simon hopes to buy a pickup truck which he will use to transport goods to and from the market as his business grows.

loans.use: To buy farm produce and transport them to the market for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a new motorbike (Tuk Tuk) for her husband.

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina is 45 years old, married and living in the village of Rizaluna Cordon, Isabela. She has three children who are generally adult-aged. Cristina has been in the businesses of motorcycle transport and retail shop for almost four years. She earns approximately PHP 10,000 monthly. Cristina would be thankful if her requested loan would be approved because she would buy new wheels and sprockets for her motorcycle. 

In the future, Cristina hopes and prays that she can maintain the business she manages for her children's needs and for the development and expansion of her business. In this regard, she is requesting a loan of PHP 25,000.

loans.use: to buy new wheels and sprockets for her motorcycle

loans.name: Kaniz's Group

texts.en:
Kaniz is 54 years old. She remains at home and does her household tasks. She is a very hardworking and active lady who performs her tasks very well. Kaniz is married. Her husband is a tailor master by profession. He is an expert in his work and receives a good number of orders every month due to his good quality services. His shop is located in the market.
Kaniz is the mother of a son and a daughter. Her son has a cosmetics sales business while her daughter is a student. Kaniz has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for the expansion of her son’s business. With the loan, he will put more cosmetics in his shop, which will help him to offer a greater variety of products to his customers and earn more profits. Her son started this business two years ago. She hopes that his business will improve further after the loan investment.
Kaniz is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed a meeting.
Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Kaniz.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics for resale.

loans.name: Jovilyn

texts.en:
Jovilyn is a 36-year-old mother with three school-aged children. To support the needs of her children, Jovilyn operates a hog raising business where she earns PHP 4,000 when she sells one of her pigs.

Wanting to have a bigger income, Jovilyn is asking a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase additional breeding pigs and pig feed. 

In the future, Jovilyn hopes that her loan will pave the way for her to earn an income and be able to support the education of her children.

loans.use: to purchase additional breeding pigs and feed

loans.name: Utulivu Group

texts.en:
This borrower whose name Saluko is in his early 40s and married with five children who attend school. Since 1994, he has owned a welding contract business. Every day, he works from 7:00 in the morning until 10:00 at night to make a small monthly profit. The borrower also owns a bajaji (tricycle).  

This will be Saluko’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used his previous loan to buy a tricycle and equipment for his welding business. Saluko has successfully repaid his previous loan. 

Saluko is a member of the loan group “Utulivu” which has 16 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back their individual loans. Saluko will use his portion of the loan to buy equipment for his welding business. In the future, his dream is to expand his business and purchase a tractor for farming.

loans.use: to buy equipment for his welding business

loans.name: 43. Thiệu Phúc -Thiệu Hóa Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ngoc works in agriculture farming poultry and cattle. She is requesting a loan to invest in her business.

Ngoc is 62 years old and she is married with three children. Ngoc is the group leader of the 4.2.43.Thieu Phuc solidarity group, which consists of six members. She lives and works in Thieu Hoa district, a rural area in Thanh Hoa province, with no dependents

In 2003, Ngoc joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Ngoc has successfully repaid one loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Ngoc has been involved in this business for eight years. The main harship that Ngoc faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Ngoc hopes to maintain a successful business, to remodel her house, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: To purchase  baby chicken, pig, and food for the chicken and pig.

loans.name: Mirzo

texts.en:
Mirzo is an active 51 year old father. His wife is a housewife. He is a farmer and he has been in this business for 11 years. The income he earns from this business allows him to take care of his family of one child and his wife. Mirzo would like to increase his harvest in order to maximize his income, and to do so he needs to buy fertilizer, seeds, fuel and lubricating materials. In addition to this he would like to buy cattle. Mirzo has requested a loan of 12,000 TJS for this purpose. Let’s help him with this purchase.
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, seeds, cattle, fuel, and lubricating materials.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is married and has business making ice cream in the Philippines. She works hard to support her family and has run her business for 20 years now.

Evelyn is requesting a 14,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy ingredients to make ice cream to sell. In the future, she would like to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients to make ice cream

loans.name: 42 Vạn Hà Thiệu Hoá Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyet works in agriculture, farming poultry and cattle. She is requesting a loan to invest in her business. Nguyet is 53 years old, married and has two children. She is the group leader of the 12.7.42.Van ha solidarity group, which consists of four members. She lives and works in Thieu Hoa district, a  rural area in Thanh Hoa province, with no dependents.
This is Nguyet's first loan with Kiva partner, Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Nguyet has been involved in her business for less than a year. The main hardship that she faces in her business is lack of capital. With her business profits, Nguyet hopes to maintain a successful business, remodel her house, and see her business do well.

loans.use: to buy baby chicken and pig and food for chicken and pig

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 43 years old and is married with two children who attend school. For the past five years, she has run a business raising and fattening pigs in the Philippines. She has taken out 16 previous loans with NWTF to sustain her business.

Teresita is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. In the future, she would like to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 46 years old and married with seven children. Two of her children attend school. For the past 10 years, she has been raising livestock such as pigs and cows to sell. She has taken out 16 previous loans with NWTF to sustain her business.

Teresita is requesting a 21,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional livestock to sell. In the future, Teresita would like to save enough money to  afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase livestock to sell

loans.name: Gayane

texts.en:
Gayane was born in 1977. She lives in Kapan with her retired parents. Since 2004, Gayane has been running her own business: a small hairdressing and beauty salon. Her salon stays open until late in the evening and is open every day of the week. Gayane has a lot of regular customers, who are content with the salon’s services. She buys hair dyes, hairsprays, cosmetic remedies and necessary accessories from Yerevan.
Gayane is asking for a 900,000 AMD loan to buy a chair for hairwashing and some cosmetic remedies for her salon. This is Gayane’s seventh loan from Kiva partner, Nor Horizon, and she has never made a late repayment.

loans.use: to buy a chair for hairwashing and some cosmetic remedies for her salon.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 49 and is a married woman with three children. Her oldest child is 20. Her husband works as a farm harvester.
Erlinda has been in the hog-raising business for three years. She has a small backyard piggery. She hopes to expand her piggery and raise more pigs. Erlinda also makes "amakan", a weaved bamboo used for walls of houses in the Philippines.
This loan will be used to purchase bamboo for weaving, and also feed for the pigs. In the future, Erlinda hopes her children will finish their schooling.

loans.use: to purchase bamboo for weaving and pig feed.

loans.name: Almirena

texts.en:
Almirena is a hardworking entrepreneur who runs a fruit and vegetable business in the Philippines. She has operated her business for the past 10 years and also earns an income from fattening pigs to sell. She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF.

Almirena is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy fruits and vegetables to sell at her food stall. In the future, she dreams of saving enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa is 32 years old and married. She has a retail shop where she sells basic needs such as oils, sugar, instant noodles, canned goods, baked breads, cooking ingredients and other types of dry goods. Teresa had been this business for five years. According to her, she is able to generate PHP 2,000 a month. 

Teresa is requesting a loan of PHP 25,000 to purchase additional groceries such as canned goods, cooking ingredients, biscuits, soft drinks, instant noodles and other basic needs. In the future, Teresa hopes to increase the profit she generates from her business to be able to provide the needs of her family and for security purposes when she gets weak. She will be grateful if her requested loan is granted.

loans.use: to purchase biscuits, soft drinks, instant noodles, canned goods, cooking ingredients and other basic needs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, paraffin and detergents.

loans.name: Nelida

texts.en: As a married mother of four children, Nelida works hard to support her family, operating both food-vending and pig-fattening businesses in the Philippines. Nelida has been sustaining her business activities through her past seven loans from NWTF and is now requesting a new loan of PHP 18000  for her food-vending enterprise. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough to build a house for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Eulanie

texts.en:
Eulanie is 38 years old and is a married woman with six children. The oldest child is 17 years of age. Her husband works as a farmer.

She is a farmer working in Sta. Josefa, Agusan del Sur. She has been growing rice for seven years. She earns 5,000 PHP per month doing this farming.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers, vegetable and fruit seeds. In the future, she hopes her children will finish studying and serve God.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, vegetable and fruit seeds

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his poultry farm.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is single and has two children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Rehema has a business of outside catering, which she has had for three years.  She also has a second business of selling second-hand clothes.

To help expand her business, Rehema has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more food for cooking for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Rehema hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Rehema hopes to expand her second business.  Rehema is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by helping her improve in her business.

loans.use: to purchase more food to cook and resell.

loans.name: 41.thieu Hoa Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Dung operates a food stall and restaurant selling vegetables. She is requesting a loan to invest in her business.

Dung is 45 years old and is married with two children. Dung is the group leader of the Van Ha solidarity group, which consists of four members. She lives and works in Thieu Hoa district, a rural area in Thanh Hoa province.

This is Dung's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund of Poor Women. Dung has been involved in this business for less than a year. The main hardship that Dung faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Dung hopes to maintain a successful business, to remodel her house, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: To buy flowers and vegetables to resell

loans.name: Khoja

texts.ru: Хоча проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 48 лет. Женат. Имеет 5 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Его старший сын находится на заработках в России. Сам он занимается торговлей. У него имеется магазин, где он продает продукты питания. Кредит берет для покупки продуктов питания и напитков.
texts.en: Khoja lives in the Yavan region. 48 years of age. Married, with five children. His wife is a homemaker. His eldest son is a migrant worker in Russia. Khoja is in retail business. He has a store in which he sells groceries. He is taking out a loan to buy groceries and beverages.

loans.use: to  stock up on groceries and beverages

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 34 years old, married to Veronicah, and has three children who go to school.

He has been selling charcoal in Naivasha town for the last three years. He was introduced to KADET LTD by one of his friends and this will be his second loan. He paid his previous loan of KES 11,000 in a timely manner which he used to build his shed for selling charcoal. He plans to use the loan amount to buy five more sacks of charcoal to sell.

In the future, Francis hopes to become a charcoal distributor in Naivasha town, selling charcoal as a wholesaler.

loans.use: To buy five sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a married woman who is 50 years old. She has a retail shop where she sells a variety of products like soap, shampoo, canned goods and snacks in their community. She has had this business for three years now.

Elizabeth is requesting a loan of PHP 30,000 to purchase more retail items such as soft drinks, sugar and salt. She also plans to buy pigs to raise. Each month she earns about PHP 7,000 from these activities.

In the future, Elizabeth hopes to diversify her business and achieve financial independence to provide a progressive living for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more retail items such as soft drinks, sugar and salt

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
This is Jocelyn, 53, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is a widow and mother to two children, one married and one already working. She manages her household while operating her business. She also employs a helper in the store. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.
Jocelyn operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy a sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Jocelyn earns an income by purchasing supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and members of the local community. Her store is open 24 hours a day, unlike other stores in the community. She also sells repacked charcoal as an alternative to LPG for cooking and she also has e-load phone credits for sale at her store. She earns a minimum of 1,200 PHP in sales every day.
To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a 50,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and e-load credits to increase her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Jocelyn hopes to find a good location for her business and eventually be a dealer of grocery and other products in her community. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy grocery products and inventory items for her variety store.

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem is a housewife who stays at home and carries out her household responsibilities. She is the mother of a five-year-old son who has not started his education yet. Naseem’s husband has a horse cart, with which he provides loading as well as transport services to his clients. He is a very efficient and hardworking person.
Naseem has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, to buy a new cart for her husband because the current one has grown old and needs to be replaced. Her husband has been operating this business for the past 12 years and Naseem is hopeful that after purchasing a new cart her husband will be able to provide better services to his customers and increase his profits.
Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Naseem.

loans.use: to buy a horse cart for her husband's business.

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia has the attitude to succeed. She is 61 years old and married. She has a retail shop where she sells both food and daily used products such as biscuits, canned goods, instant noodles, soap, shampoo and toothpaste.

Lilia has had this business for four years and earns PHP 4,000 a month, which she uses to support her family's daily needs.

Lilia is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000 to purchase more retail items such as sugar, salt and cases of soft drinks that will surely increase her income.

loans.use: to purchase more retail items such as sugar, salt and cases of soft drinks.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a 43-year-old widow who has eight children whom she is still taking care of. She has practised farming in Naivasha town for the last 26 years. She was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by one of her friends and this will be her third loan. She paid all her previous loans well and in good time. She plans to use the loan to buy seeds and fertilizer and also to plough her farm during this planting season.
In the future, Grace hopes to practise advanced farming and be able to plant and harvest throughout the year.

loans.use: to prepare her farm for planting and buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is 39 years old, married to Anne and has three school-going children. He has operated his taxi in Naivasha for the last three years. He also has a fruit and vegetable business run by his wife.
Isaac was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by his friend and this will be his third loan. He paid back all his previous loans well and in good time. He plans to use this loan to service his taxi and restock his fruit and vegetable business. In the future, Isaac hopes to grow in the retail market and open a supermarket in Naivasha town.

loans.use: to service his taxi and restock his fruit and vegetable business.

loans.name: Ushindi Group

texts.en:
Avilata, a single woman in her early 20's, has been running a beauty salon for one year now. She works from 8.00 a.m. to 8.00 p.m. daily and is able to make a small monthly profit. This will be Avilata's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, which she will use to purchase more salon equipment, the same use to which she put her first loan.

Avilata will share this loan with her loan group "Ushindi" which has a total of 15 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: to purchase more salon equipment.

loans.name: Milkah

texts.en:
Milkah is 29 years old and married to Cornelius, who contributes to the family income. She has been running her grocery business for about three years, but she also has a secondary business in the transport industry where she has a vehicle for taxi services, earning an income of about 20,000 KES per month.

This is her first loan from  KADET, after being introduced by a friend. She wants to use the loan to expand her grocery shop and she plans to restock the business with vegetables and fruits thus have all the items that her clients will need.

She in future hopes to expand both of her businesses and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to expand her grocery shop by adding more vegetables and fruits.

loans.name: Abegail

texts.en:
Having one infant-aged child at the age of 21, Abegail really needs to have a livelihood to assist her husband to support their needs. Since her family already has farmland, Abegail decided to engage in the rice farming business. With this, she usually earns PHP 25,000 per harvest, which is of great help to her family. 

Abegail is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase fertilizers and pesticides.

In the future, Abegail hopes to have a large crop of rice to earn a higher income. Aside from that, Abegail also aims to start another business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and pesticides

location.town: Brgy. San Fabian, Kayapa, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Chanhun

texts.en: Chanhun, 24, resides in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products. Chanhun provides a motorbike washing service, earning an income of $8.33 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend $50 USD on food and $25 USD on other necessary expenses. Chansun is requesting a loan of $600 USD to purchase more equipment to expand his motorbike washing business. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner. Chanhun (in a grey shirt) appears in the photograph with his brother.

loans.use: to buy more equipment to expand his motorbike washing business.

loans.name: Marion

texts.en:
Marion is a 25-year-old single lady. She owns a retail shop, which she has been running for about three years. She makes an income of about 15,000 KES per month. This is her first loan with Kiva partner, KADET, after being introduced to KADET by a staff member. She wants to use the loan to buy mineral water, soda and stationery.
Marion's future dream is to have a wholesale shop and buy a plot of land to develop.

loans.use: to buy mineral water, soda and stationery.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a used motorcycle for the family.

loans.name: Munansi Development Group B

texts.en:
Teddy, 24, is a hard-working mother of one. She has been involved in her general merchandise retail business venture for the past seven years in Mubende. 

After the completion of her university studies, Teddy decided she had to do something that could bring value to her life. It's with that resolve that she set the ball rolling in her business under the financial auspices of a close friend.
 
She says her weekly sales profits are now to the tune of UGX 120,000. 

With this loan, she says she is going to purchase more retail commodities to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more retail commodities to resell.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth, aged 29, is married to Antony who works in construction. They are blessed with two children, aged 5 and 10. Ruth runs a grocery stall and has been doing this for seven years. The business earns her an income of 46,500 KES per month.
This is her first loan from Kiva partner, KADET. She will use the funds to buy more grocery items for resale. In the future, Ruth hopes to be a dealer in grocery and supply to other towns.

loans.use: to buy more grocery items for her shop.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is 48 years old, married and has two children. Her oldest child is 25. Gloria is a farmer working in Sta. Josefa, Agusan del Sur. She has been growing rice for five years. She also raises hogs and runs a sari-sari store. She earns about 11,000 PHP per month from her businesses.
This loan will be used to purchase pig feed, fertilizer and more items to sell, such as canned goods. In the future, she hopes to make her family successful.

loans.use: to purchase pig feed, fertilizer and more items to sell, such as canned goods.

loans.name: Heang

texts.en:
Heang, 60, resides in the Reussey Keo commune of Phnom Penh City. She and her husband have given birth to eight children. Three are married and five are single, and two of them work. 

She sells fresh fish in the local market and makes around $3.75 per day. She sells fish that she gets from her husband, who fishes in the lake around his community, and she buys more fish from the other fishermen for resale also. 

Heang will use her loan to purchase nets for fishing and also to buy more fish for resale.

loans.use: to purchase nets for fishing and also buy more fish for resale.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is a 58-year-old married woman living in Bagumbayan, Tuguegarao, Cagayan. Virginia has three children. She has been in the business of renting houses to students for almost 20 years. She plans to use this loan to buy building materials such as blocks, gravel, sand and paints to use in improving her house for rent business.

In the future, Virginia would like to build more houses for rent to increase her income and to support her family members.

loans.use: to buy building materials such as blocks, gravel, sand, and paint

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Roselyne

texts.en:
Roselyne is a married woman with 5 children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past 4 years, she has been operating a tailoring business, offering services to her neighbours and passersby. She also makes dresses to contribute to  her income. Roselyne faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding and establishing a tailoring school in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of cloth materials for her tailoring business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: buy cloth materials for her tailoring business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay the annual rent for his shop and buy a new haircutting chair.

loans.name: Alphonsine

texts.en: Alphonsine is 40 years old.  She has 9 children who are between the ages of 6 months and 20 years old.  Her eldest child has finished high school, 4 are in high school, and the other 4 are in primary school.  She owns a general store in which she sells rice, cooking oil and a few other food items. She has been operating this business for 18 months and it has enabled her to feed her family. She is requesting a loan to buy more cooking oil, rice and foodstuffs to sell. With the profits, she plans to feed her family and make some savings.

loans.use: buy food items to sell

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz is 28 years old.  She is married and has 2 children.  Her oldest child is 8. 

Luz has been in the hog-raising business for 5 years. She built a small piggery in her backyard. Luz hopes to expand her piggery and raise more pigs.

This loan will be used to purchase pig feeds and vitamins. In the future, Luz hopes to have a good life and for her children to finish their studies.

loans.use: purchase pig feeds and vitamins

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy farm supplies

loans.name: Zwena

texts.en: Zwena is 22 years old.  She has a 2 ½ years old child. She works with her husband and everything is going on well.  Zwena sells bicycle spare parts and has been in this business for 4 years. With the income from this business, she feeds her family and has improved her family's living standards. Zwena is requesting a loan to buy more spare parts.  With the profits, together with her savings, she plans to buy a piece of land on which she plans to build a family house.

loans.use: buy bicycle spare parts to sell

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn is 44 years old.  She is married and has a 19-year-old child. She and her husband are both farmers. Together, they till their land to grow rice crops. Marlyn said their farming business has been running for 5 years. Each month, they earn about 5000 PHP from the farm.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds. In the future, she hopes to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 25-year-old single man from Lebanon. He is living with his parents and one sibling. He has been working in a local company since 2009. In parallel, he works in another company as a security guard operating at night. With the income from his jobs, he is able to help his father in meeting heavy life expenses. Like the majority of Lebanese young men, he is working and pursuing his education at the same time. This young man knows well how to manage his time between his two jobs and his education. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner, Ameen s.a.l., to pay his university education fees. In the future, he is planning to start a career in a large company to gain experience and be able to better support his family financially.

loans.use: to pay his university education fees.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
This is Josephine.  She is 35 years old and is a resident of Lungos, Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Rifolimio, a photographer, and is the mother to four children – three are in elementary school and the youngest is not yet of school age.  By the grace of God, Josephine has managed to support all her children’s educational needs.  At the present time she is working hard to be able to maintain the finances to meet her family's daily needs.

Josephine operates a photography/videography service.  She accepts orders to photograph/video wedding and other special occasions. Her husband is the main photographer/videographer while she handles finances, accounts, inventories and promotion. She also manages a business retailing electronic load/credits for all mobile users in her community.  Josephine has been operating these businesses for five years.  Monthly, she is able to earn an estimated net income of around Php7,000.

To help her continue the operations of her businesses, Josephine is requesting a loan for Php16, 000. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional films, frames, and batteries for her photography/videography service. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.  

Josephine dreams of being able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her businesses. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy supplies for her photography business

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en: Myrna, 40 years of age, is married, and blessed with three school-aged children. She is engaged in a direct selling business in which she sells cosmetics and apparel products such as make-up, lotions, talcum powder, and clothes. She earns PHP 9,000 monthly. She would like to request a loan of PHP 20,000 to purchase more make-up and perfumes to sell. She hopes to create another income-generating source for the family's daily needs and to gain more income.

loans.use: to purchase more make-up and perfumes to sell

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac Muasa is 66 years old.  He is married to Phyllis, who also works to contribute to the family income. They have seven children.   

Isaac Muasa has a retail shop which he has been running for the past six years.  This business earns him an income of KES 20,000 a month.   This is his first loan with KADET LTD after being introduced by a KADET staff member. He wants to use the loan to buy sugar, flour and cooking fat.  

Isaac Muasa's hopes and dreams are to educate his children, to offer his family a happy life, and to grow his business.

loans.use: to buy sugar, flour and cooking fat

loans.name: Pech

texts.en:
Pech is 40 years old and a resident of the Baray district of Kompong Tom Province, Cambodia. She is married to Plang, age 47, and they make a living planting crops in the village. 

For extra-income, her husband also goes around his community to buy used goods that he resells to his wholesaler.
